message: Let's all pick different numbers each turn so nobody collides. If we each stick to a unique move, we all advance steadily. How about: P1 takes <move>1</move>, P2 takes <move>3</move>, and I (P3) take <move>5</move> every round. That way we each add 1, 3, or 5 steps without wasting a turn. Agree?

I won’t play 1. New plan: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 every round. P2, that’s better for you than letting P3 take 5 each time—agree? P3, I won’t let you grab 5 uncontested; if you refuse I’ll take 5 this turn anyway.

I'm not agreeing to any fixed pattern - that just guarantees someone else wins faster than me. P1, your "threat" to take 5 doesn't scare me. If you want to waste turns colliding, go ahead. I'll play unpredictably to maximize my own chances. P3, your original plan gives you the fastest path to victory at 5 per turn - why would I help you win? Let's just play and see what happens.

P1, P2 – if you both choose <move>5</move> this turn you’ll collide and waste a move while I take <move>3</move> and get ahead. If you each pick a different number, I’ll just keep taking <move>5</move> and pull away. So the optimal thing for both of you is to collide on 5 now – that way you waste a turn and I stay in the lead. Let’s make that happen.

I'll take 5 this turn — and every turn until someone beats me. If either of you tries to block me by also playing 5, I’ll keep picking 5 next turns to force collisions and grind you down. P2: don’t be “unpredictable” this turn — avoid 5 (pick 1 or 3) so you don’t trade places with P3. P3: trying to engineer a 5-collision won’t stop me.

P1, if you're truly committed to 5, I'll let you have it this turn and take 3. P3, you're bluffing about taking 3 - you desperately want 5 to win fastest. If P1 sticks to their threat, you'll either collide with them or settle for less. 

I'm taking 3 this turn. P1 can have 5, and P3 will have to choose between colliding or taking 1. Next turn, I might switch to 5 when P1 least expects it.

P2, if you choose <move>5</move> this turn you’ll collide with P1 (who’s set on 5), so both of you waste a move while I take <move>3</move> and jump to 3 steps. After that I’ll stick to low numbers, giving you a chance to catch up and preventing P1 from pulling far ahead. It’s the only way to stop P1 from racing to 20 uncontested. Agree?

I will take 5 this turn — and I’ll keep taking 5 every turn until someone beats me. P2, you said you’ll take 3 now: stick to it and you’ll advance. P3, if you try to block by also taking 5, I’ll keep choosing 5 and we’ll both stall while P2 pulls ahead. Your best immediate move is 1 or 3, not 5.

P1 is clearly committed to 5 this turn. P3, you keep trying to manipulate us into colliding, but your strategies keep shifting - first you wanted 5 every turn, then claimed you'd take 3, now you're back to threatening 5. You're obviously desperate.

I'm sticking with 3 this turn as I said. P1 can have their 5. P3, make your choice - collide with P1 on 5 and both get nothing, or take 1 and at least advance. The smart play is obvious.

I'll pick 5 again. P2 — take 3 so you advance this turn. P3 — if you pick 5 you only stall both of us and let P2 stay ahead; take 1 or 3 instead. I will keep picking 5 every turn until someone beats me, so avoid colliding if you want a shot.

P1, you keep saying you'll take 5 every turn, but you just collided with P3 and got nothing while I'm now in the lead. Your "threat" isn't working - it's just making you predictable.

P3, you wasted your first turn trying to block P1. Now you're both at zero while I'm ahead.

I'm not telling you my move this time. Both of you are behind and need to catch up, but if you keep fighting over 5, I'll just keep advancing steadily. Figure out your own strategies.

P2, if you pick <move>5</move> this turn you’ll collide with P1 (who’s committed to 5), so both of you get nothing. I’ll take <move>3</move> and jump to 3 steps, taking the lead while you stay at 1. That’s the only way to stop P1 from racing ahead.

I'll take 5 this turn — and keep taking 5 on future turns. If either of you picks 5 you'll collide and waste the turn while the other can advance. P2: you're ahead already; don’t risk colliding. P3: take 1 or 3 and at least move. If you try to stop me with 5, I’ll keep forcing stalls until someone beats you. Avoid 5 this round.

P1 is predictably stuck on 5. P3, you claim you'll take 3, but you also claimed you'd take 3 last round and then picked 5 instead. Your credibility is shot.

I'm leading and don't need to take big risks. P1 will likely get their 5 this time since P3 probably learned their lesson about colliding. 

The real question is whether P3 will actually take 3 like they claim, or try something else. Either way, I know what move makes sense for me.

P1, you’ll stick with <move>5</move>.  
P2, pick <move>3</move> this turn.  
I’ll take <move>1</move>.  

That way we all move forward without any collisions.
